docs.lead_paragraph: To combat the mosquito that carries the Zika virus, experts say the United States will need a “guerrilla warfare house-to-house method” of control.

headline.main: Prepare for ‘Guerrilla Warfare’ With Zika-Carrying Mosquitoes, Experts Warn
headline.print_headline: Mosquito Experts in U.S. Call for Guerrilla War Against Zika

docs.snippet: To combat the mosquito that carries the Zika virus, experts say the United States will need a “guerrilla warfare house-to-house method” of control.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Zika virus may be particularly adept at entrenching itself in parts of the body that are shielded from the immune system, making it harder to fight off and possibly lengthening the timeframe in which it can be transmitted, top U.S. experts said on Friday.

headline.main: Zika Virus May Hide in Organs Protected From the Immune System
headline.print_headline: Zika Virus May Hide in Organs Protected From the Immune System

docs.lead_paragraph: Florzinha Amado is eight months pregnant and trying to stay calm about whether the Zika virus infection she contracted at 21 weeks could have harmed her unborn child.

docs.lead_paragraph: The virus, which has been around in Asia for decades, first hit hard on Yap Island, and spread across the Pacific, with a huge outbreak now in Brazil.

headline.main: Experts Study Zika’s Path From First Outbreak in Pacific
headline.print_headline: Once a Scientific Curiosity, Zika First Emerged in Force on a Remote Pacific Island

docs.abstract: Scientists scrambling to understand and counter Zika virus outbreak trace its emergence to tiny Yap island in Western Pacific; researchers piece together how once-mild virus with origins in Africa and history in Asia became current robust strain that has infected around 1.5 million Brazilians.
docs.snippet: The virus, which has been around in Asia for decades, first hit hard on Yap Island, and spread across the Pacific, with a huge outbreak now in Brazil.

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organisation advised women on Wednesday on how to protect themselves from Zika, particularly if pregnant, but also reassured them that most women in areas affected by the mosquito-borne virus will give birth to "normal infants."

headline.main: WHO Advises Women on Zika Protection but No Travel Advisories
headline.print_headline: WHO Advises Women on Zika Protection but No Travel Advisories

docs.snippet: The World Health Organisation advised women on Wednesday on how to protect themselves from Zika, particularly if pregnant, but also reassured them that most women in areas affected by the mosquito-borne virus will give birth to "normal infants."

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty of the world's leading scientific research institutions, journals and funders have pledged to share for free all data and expertise on Zika to speed up the fight against an outbreak of the viral disease spreading across the Americas.

headline.main: World's Top Scientists Pledge to Share All Findings to Fight Zika
headline.print_headline: World's Top Scientists Pledge to Share All Findings to Fight Zika

docs.snippet: Thirty of the world's leading scientific research institutions, journals and funders have pledged to share for free all data and expertise on Zika to speed up the fight against an outbreak of the viral disease spreading across the Americas.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health advisers on Tuesday endorsed a lower-cost version of Johnson & Johnson's blockbuster Remicade, a pricey biotech medicine used to treat a number of inflammatory diseases.

headline.main: FDA Panel Backs Lower-Cost Version of J&J's Top-Selling Drug

docs.lead_paragraph: Understanding how infections like rubella injure fetuses may aid research into the potential link between Zika and microcephaly.

headline.main: Scientists Investigate How Viruses Like Zika Cause Birth Defects
headline.print_headline: A Search for Answers From Other Epidemics

docs.abstract: Research into other viruses that negatively affect developing fetuses, like rubella, is providing guidance in midst of Zika virus sweeping Latin America.
docs.snippet: Understanding how infections like rubella injure fetuses may aid research into the potential link between Zika and microcephaly.
